info: Feminine form of Aali. It was popularized in the English-speaking world by the singer Aaliyah Haughton (1979-2001), who was known simply as Aaliyah. This name received a boost in popularity after she released her debut album in 1994, and again in 2001 after her untimely death in an airplane crash.
Alternate transcription of Arabic آمنة (see Amina), as well as the Somali form.

Means "her father" in Arabic. Umm Abiha, meaning "the mother of her father", was a kunya (nickname) of the Prophet Muhammad's daughter Fatima. It was supposedly given to her by her father as a sign of affection.
Means "virtuous" in Arabic. It is typically feminine in the Arab world, and typically masculine in Pakistan, India and Bangladesh.
Alternate transcription of Arabic عفيفة (see Afifa), as well as the usual Indonesian and Malay form.
Form of Aisha used in North Africa and other French-influenced regions of the continent.

source: Arabic, Bosnian, Albanian, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Tatar, Bashkir, Literature
info: Variant of Ayda. This name was used in Verdi's opera Aida (1871), where it belongs to an Ethiopian princess held captive in Egypt.

source: Arabic, Urdu, Hausa, Swahili, Kyrgyz, Kazakh, African American
info: Means "living, alive" in Arabic. This was the name of Muhammad's third wife, the daughter of Abu Bakr. Some time after Muhammad's death she went to war against Ali, the fourth caliph, but was defeated. Her name is used more by Sunni Muslims and less by Shias.... [more]
Alternate transcription of Arabic عائشة (see Aisha), as well as the usual Malay form.
Alternate transcription of Arabic عقيلة (see Aqila).
Feminine form of Ali 1. This can also be another way of transcribing the related name عالية (see Aaliyah).
Means "diamond" in Arabic, Urdu and Kazakh, ultimately from Persian الماس (almās). It is typically feminine in Pakistan and masculine in Kazakhstan.
Alternate transcription of Arabic آمال (see Aamaal) chiefly used in North Africa.

source: Arabic, Urdu, Chechen, Ingush, Bosnian, Swahili, Hausa, Kyrgyz, Kazakh, Tatar, Bashkir
info: Derived from Arabic أمن (ʾamina) meaning "safe, secure". This was the name of the Prophet Muhammad's mother, who died when he was young.... [more]
Alternate transcription of Arabic آمنة or أمينة (see Amina), as well as the usual form in Malay and Indonesian.
Alternate transcription of Arabic أميرة (see Amira 1), as well as the usual Malay form.
Means "safety" in Arabic, derived from أمن (ʾamina) meaning "to be safe".
Means "farthest, most distant" in Arabic. It is taken from the name of the Al-Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem, considered the third holiest site in Islam.
Alternate transcription of Arabic أريج (see Arij), as well as the usual Urdu form.

Possibly from Arabic أسي (ʾasiya) meaning "to be distressed, to be grieved". According to Islamic tradition this was the name of the wife of the pharaoh at the time of Moses. She took care of the infant Moses and later accepted monotheism.
Means "supreme, higher" in Arabic, a derivative of the root سما (samā) meaning "to be high". This was the name of a daughter of Abu Bakr, the first caliph of the Muslims.
Alternate transcription of Arabic آسيا or آسية (see Asiya) chiefly used in North Africa.
Means "returning, visitor" in Arabic. In Turkey this is also associated with ay meaning "moon".
Alternate transcription of Arabic عائشة or Urdu عائشہ (see Aisha), as well as the usual Bengali transcription.
Alternate transcription of Arabic عائشة or Urdu عائشہ (see Aisha) or Kazakh Айша (see Aişa).
